sen.j: 細川 勝元（ほそかわ かつもと）は、室町時代の守護大名、室町幕府の管領、三管領のひとつである細川氏嫡流・細川氏の当主。
sen.e: Katsumoto HOSOKAWA was a Shugo (military governor) daimyo in the Muromachi period, a shogunal deputy or a chief official of the Ashikaga shogunate, and was the head of the Hosokawa family, one of the so-called the three shogunal deputies, in the main Hosokawa family line which was so-called the three.

Katsumoto HOSOKAWA was a shugo (military governor) daimyo in the Muromachi period, a shogunal deputy or a chief official of the Ashikaga shogunate, and the head of the Hosokawa family (as one of the so-called three shogunal deputies) in the main Hosokawa family line.

Katsumoto HOSOKAWA was a shugo (military governor) daimyo in the Muromachi period, a kanrei (shogunal deputy or a chief official) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and the head of the Hosokawa clan (as one of the so-called three shogunal deputies) in the main Hosokawa clan line.
sen.cmt: Hosokawa family→Hosokawa clankanrei補足shogunal deputy or a chief officialに括弧を補足Ashikaga shogunate→Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)

sen.j: 官位は右京大夫従四位。
sen.e: His official rank was Ukyo no Daibu Jyuyoi, which was the Minister of the Kyoto Right Administration Office with junior fourth court rank.
His official rank was Ukyo no Daibu Jyuyoi, meaning that he was the minister of the Kyoto Right Administration Office with the junior fourth court rank.
His official rank was Ukyo no Daibu Jushii, meaning that he was the minister of the Kyoto Right Administration Office with the junior fourth court rank.

sen.j: 父は細川持之、正室は山名熙貴の娘・春林寺殿（山名宗全の養女）。
sen.e: His father was Mochiyuki HOSOKAWA, and his official wife was Shunrinji-dono (an adopted daughter of Sozen YAMANA), a daughter of Hirotaka YAMANA.
His father was Mochiyuki HOSOKAWA, and his official wife was Shunrinji-dono, a daughter of Hirotaka YAMANA and the adopted child of Sozen YAMANA.
His father was Mochiyuki HOSOKAWA, and his official wife was Shunrinji-dono, a daughter of Hirotaka YAMANA and the adopted child of Sozen YAMANA.

sen.j: 子は細川政元、洞松院（赤松政則室）、養子に山名豊久、猶子に細川勝之がいる。
sen.e: His children were Masamoto HOSOKAWA and Tosho-in (Masanori AKAMATSU's concubine), and he also had an adopted child Toyohisa YAMANA and another child considered as one's own called Katsuyuki HOSOKAWA.

His children were Masamoto HOSOKAWA and Tosho-in (Masanori AKAMATSU's concubine), and he also had an adopted child Toyohisa YAMANA and another child considered as his own, who was called Katsuyuki HOSOKAWA.

His children were Masamoto HOSOKAWA and Tosho-in (Masanori AKAMATSU's concubine), and he also had an adopted child Toyohisa YAMANA and another child considered as his own, who was called Katsuyuki HOSOKAWA.

tit.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

tit.e: Succession to (the Headship of) a House and Kanreiship
Succession to (the Headship of) a House and Kanreiship
Succession to (the Headship of) a House and Kanreiship

sen.j: 永享2年（1430年）、細川持之の嫡男として生まれる。
sen.e: Katsumoto HOSOKAWA was born in 1430 as the first and real son of Mochiyuki HOSOKAWA.
Katsumoto HOSOKAWA was born in 1430 as the first true son of Mochiyuki HOSOKAWA.
Katsumoto HOSOKAWA was born in 1430 as the first true son of Mochiyuki HOSOKAWA.

sen.j: 幼名は聡明丸。
sen.e: His childhood name was Somei-maru.
His childhood name was Somei-maru.
His childhood name was Somei-maru.

sen.j: 嘉吉2年（1442年）8月、父の持之が死去したため、13歳で家督を継承した。
sen.e: Since his father Mochiyuki died in August, 1442, Katsumoto took over as head of the family.
Upon the death of his father Mochiyuki in August, 1442, Katsumoto took over as the head of the family.
Upon the death of his father Mochiyuki in August, 1442, Katsumoto took over as the head of the family at the age of 13.
sen.cmt: at the age of 13を補足しました。

sen.j: このとき第7代将軍・足利義勝から諱偏諱授与の風習を受けて勝元と名乗り、叔父の細川持賢に後見されて摂津国、丹波国、讃岐国、土佐国の守護職となった。
sen.e: At the same time, in accordance with the custom of being granted to use a portion of the real name of the superior, he borrowed one of the characters from Yoshikatsu ASHIKAGA, who was the 7th shogun of the Ashikaga shogunate, and started to call himself Katsumoto, and supported by the guardianship of Mochikata HOSOKAWA, he became the Shugo-shi of the Province of Settsu, Tamba, Sanuki and Tosa.
sen.cmt: 諱偏諱授与の風習→the custom being granted to use a portion of the character from the real name of the superior→the custom of being granted to use a portion of the real name of the superior細川持賢→Ｍｏｃｈｉｋａｔａ ＯＳＯＫＡＷＡ→Mochikata HOSOKAWA
sen.e: At the same time, in accordance with the custom of being granted the right to use a portion of the superior's real name, he borrowed one of the characters from Yoshikatsu ASHIKAGA, who was the seventh shogun of the Ashikaga shogunate, and thus called himself Katsumoto; and supported by the guardianship of Mochikata HOSOKAWA, he became the shugo-shi of the provinces of Settsu, Tamba, Sanuki and Tosa.

At the same time, in accordance with the custom of being granted the right to use a portion of the superior's real name, he borrowed one of the characters from Yoshikatsu ASHIKAGA, who was the seventh shogun of the Ashikaga shogunate, and thus called himself Katsumoto; and supported by the guardianship of his uncle, Mochikata HOSOKAWA, he became the shugo-shiki (the rank of military governor) of the provinces of Settsu, Tanba, Sanuki and Tosa.
sen.cmt: his uncle,を補足しました。shugo-shi→shugo-shiki(the rank of military govenor)を補足しました。Tamba→Tanba

sen.j: 文安2年（1445年）、畠山持国（徳本）に代わって16歳で管領職に就任すると、以後3度に渡って通算23年間も管領職を歴任し、幕政に影響力を及ぼし続けた。
sen.e: In 1445, he became a kanrei, or a shogunal deputy, when he was 16 to take over from Mochikuni (Tokumoto) HATAKEYAMA, and since then, had continued to influence the shogunate administration by serving as a kanrei at three different times for a total of 23 years.

In 1445, at 16 years of age, he became a kanrei (a shogunal deputy) and took over from Mochikuni (Tokumoto) HATAKEYAMA; from that point onward, he continued to influence the shogunate administration by serving as a kanrei at three different times for a total of 23 years.

In 1445, at 16 years of age, he became a kanrei (a shogunal deputy) and took over from Mochikuni (Tokumoto) HATAKEYAMA; from that point onward, he continued to influence the shogunate administration by serving as a kanrei at three different times for a total of 23 years.

sen.j: 勝元が管領に就任していたのは、文安2年（1445年）から宝徳元年（1449年）、享徳元年（1452年）から寛正5年（1464年）、応仁2年（1468年）2月から死去する文明 (日本)5年（1473年）5月までである。
sen.e: Katsumoto served as a kanrei, or a shogunal deputy, from 1445 to 1449, from 1452 to 1464, and from February, 1468, to May, 1473, when he died.
Katsumoto served as a kanrei (a shogunal deputy) from 1445 to 1449, from 1452 to 1464 and from February 1468 to May 1473, when he died.
Katsumoto served as a kanrei (a shogunal deputy) from 1445 to 1449, from 1452 to 1464 and from February 1468 to May 1473, when he died.

sen.j: 応仁の乱で敵対関係に至ったため、細川勝元と山名宗全は不仲であったとされているが、はじめはそうではなかった。
sen.e: Katsumoto HOSOKAWA and Sozen YAMANA were believed to be on bad terms with each other because they were in a hostile relationship during the Onin War, but their relationship was different in the beginning.

Katsumoto HOSOKAWA and Sozen YAMANA were believed to be on bad terms with each other because they had a hostile relationship during the Onin War, but in the beginning their relationship was different.

Katsumoto HOSOKAWA and Sozen YAMANA were believed to be on bad terms with each other because they had a hostile relationship during the Onin War, but in the beginning their relationship was different.

sen.j: 当時、細川家は一族全てで9ヶ国の守護であったのに対し、山名氏は赤松氏を嘉吉の乱で滅ぼした功績から旧赤松領を併せて8ヶ国の守護になっていた。
sen.e: In the beginning, the entire Hosokawa clan was in charge of 9 provinces while the Yamana family was in charge of 8 provinces including the former Akamatsu territories since the Yamana family was recognized for their achievement of defeating the Akamatsu family in the Kakitsu Incident.
sen.cmt: 赤松氏→the AKAMAYSU family→the AKAMATSU family
sen.e: Initially, the entire Hosokawa clan was in charge of nine provinces and the Yamana family was in charge of eight (including the former Akamatsu territories), since the Yamana family was recognized for the achievement of defeating the Akamatsu family in the Kakitsu Incident.

Initially, the entire Hosokawa family was in charge of nine provinces and the Yamana clan was in charge of eight (including the former Akamatsu territories), since the Yamana clan was recognized for the achievement of defeating the Akamatsu clan in the Kakitsu Incident.
sen.cmt: Hosokawa clan→Hosokawa familyYamana family→Yamana clanAkamatsu family→Akamatsu clan

sen.j: このため、勝元は持豊と争うことは得策ではないと考え、持豊の養女を正室に迎えることで協調することにしていたのである。
sen.e: For this reason, thinking that it was not wise to fight against Mochitoyo, Katsumoto decided to align with him by accepting Mochitoyo’s adopted daughter as an official wife.
For this reason, thinking it was unwise to fight against Mochitoyo, Katsumoto decided to align with him by accepting Mochitoyo’s adopted daughter as an official wife.
For this reason, thinking it was unwise to fight against Mochitoyo, Katsumoto decided to align with him by accepting Mochitoyo’s adopted daughter as an official wife.

sen.j: そのため、畠山氏で家督をめぐる内紛が起こったときには、政敵である持国を失脚させるため、舅にあたる山名持豊ともに畠山弥三郎（持国養子）を支援して持国の推す畠山義就（持国実子）を追放に追い込んだ。
sen.e: Therefore, when the Hatakeyama family had an internal fight over the reigns of the family, Katsumoto and Mochitoyo YAMANA, who had become his father-in-law, supported Yasaburo HATAKEYAMA (Mochikuni’s adopted son) to drive out Yoshinari HATAKEYAMA (Mochikuni’s real son) who was recommended by Mochikuni in order to bring Mochikuni down as he was Katsumoto’s political enemy.

Therefore, when the Hatakeyama family had an internal fight over the leadership of the family, Katsumoto and Mochitoyo YAMANA, who had become his father-in-law, supported Yasaburo HATAKEYAMA (Mochikuni’s adopted son) in driving out Yoshinari HATAKEYAMA (Mochikuni’s real son, who had been recommended by Mochikuni) in order to bring Mochikuni down, since he was Katsumoto’s political enemy.

Therefore, when the Hatakeyama clan had an internal fight over the leadership of the family, Katsumoto and Mochitoyo YAMANA, who had become his father-in-law, supported Yasaburo HATAKEYAMA (Mochikuni’s adopted son) in driving out Yoshinari HATAKEYAMA (Mochikuni’s real son, who had been recommended by Mochikuni) in order to bring Mochikuni down, since he was Katsumoto’s political enemy.

sen.j: しかし第8代将軍・足利義政や勝元が嘉吉の乱で没落した赤松氏の足利義政を支援しようとすると、赤松氏の旧領を守護国に持つ持豊は赤松氏の再興に強硬に反対した。
sen.e: However, when the 8th shogun of the Ashikaga shogunate, Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, and Katsumoto tried to support the Akamatsu family that fell in the Kakitsu Incident, Mochitoyo, who was in charge of former Akamatsu family territories, strongly opposed rebuilding of the Akamatsu family.
sen.cmt: 足利義政→Toshimasa ASHIKAGA→Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA嘉吉の乱で没落した赤松氏の足利義政を支援しようとすると→嘉吉の乱で没落した赤松氏を支援しようとすると
sen.e: However, when Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, the eighth shogun of the Ashikaga shogunate, and Katsumoto tried to support the Akamatsu family, which had fallen in the Kakitsu Incident, Mochitoyo, who was in charge of the former Akamatsu family territories, strongly opposed rebuilding the Akamatsu family.

However, when Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, the eighth shogun of the Ashikaga shogunate, and Katsumoto tried to support the Akamatsu clan, which had fallen in the Kakitsu Incident, Mochitoyo, who was in charge of the former Akamatsu clan territories, strongly opposed rebuilding the Akamatsu clan.

sen.j: このため、持豊は義政から追討を受けそうになるが、このときは勝元が弁護したため、持豊は追討を免れた（この前後に持豊は出家し、以下宗全と名乗った）。
sen.e: This event almost let Mochiyoto be hunted down and killed by Yoshimasa, but because of defense by Katsumoto, Mochitoyo escaped the situation (around this time, Mochiyoto became a priest and called himself Sozen thereafter).

This event nearly allowed Mochiyoto to be hunted down and killed by Yoshimasa, but because of the defense by Katsumoto, Mochitoyo escaped the situation (and around this time Mochiyoto became a priest and thereafter called himself Sozen).

This event nearly allowed Mochitoyo to be hunted down and killed by Yoshimasa, but because of Katsumoto's defense, Mochitoyo escaped the situation (and around this time Mochitoyo became a priest and thereafter called himself Sozen).
sen.cmt: “of the defense by Katsumoto”=>”of Katsumoto's defense, ”

sen.j: しかし山名氏の勢力が勝元の想像以上に急速に拡大したため、勝元は宗全の勢力拡大を危険視するようになり、斯波氏の家督争い（武衛騒動）でも姻戚関係から斯波義廉を支持する宗全に対し、勝元は義廉と対立する斯波義敏を支持した。
sen.e: Forces of the Yamana family however grew much more rapidly than Katsumoto expected, Katsumoto considered the expansion of Sozen’s power dangerous, and therefore, when rivalry for the head of the family (Buei disturbance) occurred in the Shiba family, Katsumoto supported Toshitoshi SHIBA who fought against Yoshikane SHIBA while Sozen supported Yoshikane SHIBA due to the affinal relationship.

The forces of the Yamana family, however, grew much more rapidly than Katsumoto had expected, and Katsumoto considered the expansion of Sozen’s power dangerous; therefore, when rivalry for the head of the family (the Buei disturbance) occurred in the Shiba family, Katsumoto supported Toshitoshi SHIBA, who fought against Yoshikane SHIBA, while Sozen supported Yoshikane SHIBA due to the fiduciary relationship.

The forces of the Yamana clan, however, grew much more rapidly than Katsumoto had expected, and Katsumoto considered the expansion of Sozen’s power dangerous; therefore, when rivalry for the head of the family (the Buei disturbance) occurred in the Shiba clan, Katsumoto supported Yoshitoshi SHIBA, who fought against Yoshikane SHIBA, while Sozen supported Yoshikane SHIBA as they were related by marriage.
sen.cmt: Yamana family→Yamana clanShiba family→Shiba clanToshitoshi→Yoshitoshi 姻戚関係（結婚によってできた関係）という意味が出るように訳し直しました。

sen.j: また、宗全がかねてから反対していた赤松氏の再興問題に関しても、勝元は積極的にこれを支援し、ついには赤松政則（赤松満祐の弟赤松義雅の孫）を加賀国半国の守護と成し、赤松家を再興させたのである。
sen.e: Also, as for the issue regarding rebuilding of the Akamatsu family that Sozen had opposed, Katsumoto actively supported rebuilding of the family, put Masanori AKAMATSU (grandson of Yoshimasa AKAMATSU and also a brother of Mitsusuke AKAMATSU) in charge of half of Kaga Province, and finally realized rebuilding of the family.
sen.cmt: 赤松政則（赤松満祐の弟赤松義雅の孫）→赤松政則（赤松満祐の弟赤松義雅の孫）→Masanori AKAMATSU (grandson of Yoshimasa AKAMATSU, brother of Mitsusuke AKAMATSU)→Masanori AKAMATSU (grandson of Yoshimasa AKAMATSU and also a brother of Mitsusuke AKAMATSU)
sen.e: Also, as for the issue regarding the rebuilding of the Akamatsu family that Sozen had opposed, Katsumoto actively supported the rebuilding of the family, put Masanori AKAMATSU (the grandson of Yoshimasa AKAMATSU and a brother of Mitsusuke AKAMATSU) in charge of half of Kaga Province, and finally realized the rebuilding of the family.

Also, as for the issue regarding the rebuilding of the Akamatsu clan that Sozen had opposed, Katsumoto actively supported the rebuilding of the family, put Masanori AKAMATSU (the grandson of Yoshimasa AKAMATSU and a brother of Mitsusuke AKAMATSU) in charge of half of Kaga Province, and finally realized the rebuilding of the family.

sen.j: さらに勝元は勘合貿易の問題から大内教弘、河野通春らと敵対していたが、宗全はこれを支援するなどしたことから、細川と山名の対立構造が生じ始めた。
sen.e: Furthermore, Katsumoto fought against Norihiro OUCHI and Michiharu KONO due to tally trade issues, but Sozen supported them, and this led to a conflict between the HOSOKAWA and YAMANA clans.
Furthermore, Katsumoto fought against Norihiro OUCHI and Michiharu KONO due to tally trade issues, but Sozen supported them, and this led to a conflict between the HOSOKAWA and YAMANA clans.
Furthermore, Katsumoto fought against Norihiro OUCHI and Michiharu KONO due to tally trade issues, but Sozen supported them, and this led to a conflict between the HOSOKAWA and YAMANA clans.

sen.j: また、はじめ継嗣がいなかった勝元は、宗全の子・山名豊久を養子にしていたが、文正元年（1466年）に実子細川政元の誕生後、豊久を廃嫡して仏門に入れるなど、関係の悪化は明白となった。
sen.e: In addition, Katsumoto, originally being heirless, adopted Toyohisa YAMANA who was the son of Sozen, but he disinherited Toyoshisa and made him enter the Buddhist priesthood after the birth of his own son Masamoto HOSOKAWA in 1466, clearly indicating their worsened relationship.

Additionally, Katsumoto, who originally had no heir, adopted Toyohisa YAMANA, who was the son of Sozen, but he disinherited Toyohisa and compelled him to enter the Buddhist priesthood after the birth of his own son Masamoto HOSOKAWA in 1466, clearly indicating their diminished relationship.

Additionally, Katsumoto, who originally had no heir, adopted Toyohisa YAMANA, who was the son of Sozen, but he disinherited Toyohisa and compelled him to enter the Buddhist priesthood after the birth of his own son Masamoto HOSOKAWA in 1466, clearly indicating their diminished relationship.

sen.j: 文正元年（1466年）、足利義政に実子の足利義尚が誕生して足利将軍家でも将軍後継者をめぐって争いが始まる。
sen.e: In 1466, Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA’s real son Yoshihisa ASHIKAGA was born, and shogun succession races started in the shogun family of Ashikaga.
In 1466, Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA’s real son Yoshihisa ASHIKAGA was born, and a race for succession to the primary leadership started in the shogun family of Ashikaga.
In 1466, Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA's biological son Yoshihisa ASHIKAGA was born, and a race for succession to the primary leadership started in the shogun family of Ashikaga.
sen.cmt: “real son” の意味が英語では不明確。→ “biological son”

sen.j: このとき、義政の側近・伊勢貞親は義政が当初後継者に指名していた足利義視の廃嫡と、義尚の将軍後継を義政に提言した。
sen.e: At this time, Sadachika ISE, who was a close retainer of Yoshimasa, recommended disinheritance of Yoshimi ASHIKAGA who was once nominated as a successor by Yoshimasa and succession of the shogun position by Yoshihisa.

At this time, Sadachika ISE, who was a close retainer of Yoshimasa, recommended the disinheritance of Yoshimi ASHIKAGA, who had once been nominated as a successor by Yoshimasa, as well as Yoshihisa's succession as the shogun.

At this time, Sadachika ISE, who was a close retainer of Yoshimasa, recommended the disinheritance of Yoshimi ASHIKAGA, who had once been nominated as a successor by Yoshimasa, as well as Yoshihisa's succession as the shogun.

sen.j: しかし義視を支持していた勝元はこれに反対する。
sen.e: Katsumoto who supported Yoshimi however opposed this idea.
However, Katsumoto, who supported Yoshimi, was opposed to the idea.
However, Katsumoto, who supported Yoshimi, was opposed to the idea.

sen.j: さらに宗全も貞親が幕府内において権勢を強めていたことを苦々しく思っていたことから、このときは勝元に賛同し共に義政に対して貞親追放を訴え、これを強硬に実現させた（文正の政変）。
sen.e: Furthermore, since Sozen was feeling bitter about Sadachika increasing his power within the government, he agreed with Katsumoto only for this time and together requested Yoshimasa to cast out Sadachika and strenuously achieved it (Bunsho political change).

Furthermore, because Sozen was embittered by Sadachika's increased power within the government, he agreed with Katsumoto only for this time and together requested that Yoshimasa cast out Sadachika; this was achieved through a concerted effort (the Bunsho political change).

Furthermore, because Sozen was embittered by Sadachika's increased power within the government, he agreed with Katsumoto only on this occasion and together requested that Yoshimasa cast out Sadachika; this was achieved through a concerted effort (the Bunsho political change).
sen.cmt: 表現スタイル。 “ only for this time”=>” only on this occasion”

sen.j: これにより将軍家内部で実力者がいなくなると、山名宗全は12月、追放されていた畠山義就を上洛させ、義政に仲介して赦免の許しを出させた。
sen.e: When the powerful figure disappeared from the shogun family, in December, Sozen YAMANA ordered Yoshinari HATAKEYAMA who was once cast out to enter Kyoto and also ordered granting of a pardon to him through Yoshimasa.

In December, when the powerful figure disappeared from the shogun family, Sozen YAMANA ordered Yoshinari HATAKEYAMA, who had once been an outcast, to enter Kyoto; moreover, he ordered that he be granted a pardon through Yoshimasa.

In December, when the powerful figure disappeared from the shogun family, Sozen YAMANA ordered Yoshinari HATAKEYAMA, who had once been an outcast, to enter Kyoto; moreover, he ordered that he be granted a pardon through Yoshimasa.

sen.j: さらに宗全は応仁元年（1467年）1月、義政に強請して勝元が支援する畠山政長（持国養子で弥三郎の弟）の管領職を取り上げて出仕停止処分に処し、代わりに宗全が支援する斯波義廉を管領に任命させたのである。
sen.e: In addition, in January, 1467, Sozen demanded Yoshimasa to deprive Masanaga HATAKEYAMA (Mochikuni’s adopted son and also a brother of Yasaburo), who was supported by Katsumoto, of his kanrei position and suspended him from servicing, and made Yoshimasa appoint Yoshikane SHIBA, who was supported by Sozen, to a kanrei, or a shogunal deputy, instead.

Additionally, in January 1467 Sozen demanded that Yoshimasa deprive Masanaga HATAKEYAMA (Mochikuni’s adopted son and a brother of Yasaburo), who was supported by Katsumoto, of his kanrei position and suspended him from serving, and instead made Yoshimasa appoint Yoshikane SHIBA, who was supported by Sozen, to the position of kanrei (a shogunal deputy).

Additionally, in January 1467 Sozen demanded that Yoshimasa deprive Masanaga HATAKEYAMA (Mochikuni’s adopted son and a brother of Yasaburo), who was supported by Katsumoto, of his kanrei position and suspended him from serving, and instead made Yoshimasa appoint Yoshikane SHIBA, who was supported by Sozen, to the position of kanrei (a shogunal deputy).

sen.j: ここに至って、勝元と宗全の武力衝突は避けられないものとなった。
sen.e: At this point, armed conflicts between Katsumoto and Sozen were inevitable.
At this point, armed conflicts between Katsumoto and Sozen were inevitable.
At this point, armed conflicts between Katsumoto and Sozen were inevitable.

sen.j: 最初の衝突は、畠山義就と畠山政長が争い、上御霊社で衝突したことから始まった（御霊合戦）。
sen.e: The first conflict started when Yoshinari HATAKEYAMA and Masanaga HATAKEYAMA finally clashed with each other at Kamigoryo-sha Shrine (Goryo battle).
sen.cmt: 上御霊社→Kami-Mitama sha, shrine〔未確認〕→Kamigoryo-sha Shrine [http://www.nichibun.ac.jp/meisyozue/kyoto/page2/ka.html]（御霊合戦）→(Mitama battle)〔未確認〕→(Goryo battle)[上御霊社の読みより推測]
sen.e: The first conflict started when Yoshinari HATAKEYAMA and Masanaga HATAKEYAMA finally clashed with each other at Kamigoryo-sha Shrine (the Battle of Goryo).
The first conflict started when Yoshinari HATAKEYAMA and Masanaga HATAKEYAMA finally clashed with each other at Kamigoryo-sha Shrine (the Battle of Goryo).

sen.j: これに対して宗全は後花園上皇・後土御門天皇を確保して義就を支援したのに対し、勝元は義政の命令で畠山家の争いに関与することを禁じられていたため、御霊合戦では静観していた。
sen.e: When this occurred, Sozen supported Yoshinari by securing the Retired Emperor Go-Hanazono and Emperor Go-Tsuchimikado and also supported, but Katsumoto on the other hand watched the event calmly as he was prohibited by Yoshimasa from letting himself be involved in the Hatayama family dispute.

When this occurred, Sozen supported Yoshinari by securing the support of Retired Emperor Go-Hanazono and Emperor Go-Tsuchimikado, but Katsumoto watched the event calmly since he was prohibited by Yoshimasa from letting himself be involved in the Hatayama family dispute.

When this occurred, Sozen supported Yoshinari by securing the support of retired Emperor Gohanazono and Emperor Gotsuchimikado, but Katsumoto watched the event calmly since he was prohibited by Yoshimasa from letting himself be involved in the Hatayama family dispute.

sen.j: このため、政長は敗れた。
sen.e: This caused Masanaga to lose the battle.
Consequently, Masanaga lost the battle.
Consequently, Masanaga lost the battle.

sen.j: しかし5月25日、天皇を擁した宗全に対して、勝元は幕府を占領して将軍を擁立し、5月26日には山名方に戦いを挑んだ（応仁の乱）。
sen.e: On May 25, however, against Sozen who had the Emperor, Katsumoto occupied the government and recruited a shogun, and on May 26, he provoked a battle against the Yamana side (Onin war).
On May 25, however, against Sozen (who had the Emperor's support), Katsumoto occupied the government and recruited a shogun, and on May 26 he provoked a battle against the Yamana side (the Onin War).
On May 25, however, against Sozen (who had the Emperor's support), Katsumoto occupied the government and recruited a shogun, and on May 26 he provoked a battle against the Yamana side (the Onin War).

sen.j: 細川勝元は東軍、山名宗全は西軍である。
sen.e: Katsumoto HOSOKAWA led the east force and Sozen YAMANA led the west force.
Katsumoto HOSOKAWA led the eastern force and Sozen YAMANA led the western force.
Katsumoto HOSOKAWA led the eastern force and Sozen YAMANA led the western force.

sen.j: 勝元は将軍・義政から宗全追討令を受領したものの、戦況は互角であった。
sen.e: Although Katsumoto received from the shogun Yoshimasa an order to hunt down and kill Sozen, they were evenly matched.
Although Katsumoto was instructed by the shogun Yoshimasa to hunt down and kill Sozen, they were evenly matched.
Although Katsumoto was instructed by the shogun Yoshimasa to hunt down and kill Sozen, they were evenly matched.

sen.j: また、娘婿の赤松政則を支援して山名領へ侵攻させたりした。
sen.e: Also, Katsumoto supported Masanori AKAMATSU, who was the adopted son-in-law, and made him invade the Yamana territory.
Also, Katsumoto supported the adopted son-in-law Masanori AKAMATSU and ordered him to invade the Yamana territory.
Also, Katsumoto supported the adopted son-in-law Masanori AKAMATSU and ordered him to invade the Yamana territory.

sen.j: そして一時は宗全に奪われていた上皇・天皇を確保するなど、次第に戦況は東軍有利に進むが、決定打は出せずにいた。
sen.e: The war situation was temporarily advantageous to the eastern force as they secured both the retired Emperor and the Emperor that Sozen once had, but they were unable to make a decisive attack.

The war situation was temporarily advantageous to the eastern force because they were able to secure both the retired Emperor and the Emperor that Sozen once had, but they were unable to make a decisive attack.

The war situation was temporarily advantageous to the eastern force because they were able to secure both the retired Emperor and the Emperor that Sozen once had, but they were unable to make a decisive attack.

sen.j: 応仁2年（1468年）閏10月、義政が伊勢貞親を復職させると、勝元は義尚を、宗全が義視を支持する立場に変わるなど、戦況も変わってゆく。
sen.e: After Yoshimasa let Sadachika ISE return to his former position in an intercalary month of October, 1468, the war situation changed as Katsumoto started to support Yoshihisa and Sozen started to support Yoshimi.

After Yoshimasa let Sadachika ISE return to his former position in the intercalary month of October 1468, the war situation changed as Katsumoto lent his support to Yoshihisa and Sozen started to support Yoshimi.

After Yoshimasa let Sadachika ISE return to his former position in the intercalary month of October 1468, the war situation changed as Katsumoto lent his support to Yoshihisa and Sozen started to support Yoshimi.

sen.j: このような中で文明4年（1472年）、宗全に和平交渉を試みるが、決裂する。
sen.e: Under these circumstances, in 1472, Katsumoto tried to negotiate a peace with Sozen, but the negotiation collapsed.
Under these circumstances, in 1472, Katsumoto tried to negotiate peace with Sozen, but the negotiation effort collapsed.
Under these circumstances, in 1472, Katsumoto tried to negotiate peace with Sozen, but the negotiation effort collapsed.

sen.j: 文明5年（1473年）3月に宿敵である宗全が死去して優位に立ったのも束の間、自身も後を追うように5月11日に死去した。
sen.e: Katsumoto dominated the situation as his longtime foe, Sozen, died in March, 1473, but soon after, on May 11, 1473, he also died.
Katsumoto dominated the situation upon the death of his longtime foe Sozen in March 1473, but soon after, on May 11, 1473, he also died.
Katsumoto dominated the situation upon the death of his longtime foe Sozen in March 1473, but soon after, on May 11, 1473, he also died.

sen.j: 享年44。
sen.e: He was 44 years old when he died.
He was 44 years old when he died.
He was 44 years old when he died.

sen.j: 後を子の細川政元が継いだ。
sen.e: His son, Masamoto HOSOKAWA, took over his position.
His son, Masamoto HOSOKAWA, took over his position.
His son, Masamoto HOSOKAWA, took over his position.

sen.j: 死因は病死と言われているが、一説では山名派による暗殺説もある。
sen.e: Although it is commonly believed that Katsumoto died of illness, there was also an assassination theory involving the Yamana faction.
Although it is commonly believed that Katsumoto died of illness, there was also an assassination theory involving the Yamana faction.
Although it is commonly believed that Katsumoto died of illness, there was also an assassination theory involving the Yamana faction.

sen.j: 禅宗を信仰し、龍安寺や竜興寺を建立し、鯉料理などにも精通していた。
sen.e: Katsumoto belonged to the Zen sect, established Ryoan-ji as well as Ryuko-ji Temples, and had extensive knowledge on Koi dishes.
Katsumoto belonged to the Zen sect, established Ryoan-ji and Ryuko-ji temples, and had extensive knowledge of Koi dishes.
Katsumoto belonged to the Zen sect, established Ryoan-ji and Ryuko-ji temples, and had extensive knowledge of Koi dishes.

sen.j: 自ら医術を研究して医書である「霊蘭集」を著しただけではなく、和歌・絵画にも優れた才能を持つ文化人であった。
sen.e: He not only studied the art of medicine and later wrote a medical book titled ‘Reiran-shu’ but also was a man of culture highly talented in waka reading and drawing.
He studied the art of medicine and later wrote a medical book titled ‘Reiran-shu’; additionally, he was a man of culture who was highly talented in drawing and waka reading.
He studied the art of medicine and later wrote a medical book titled ‘Reiran-shu’; additionally, he was a man of culture who was highly talented in drawing and waka reading.

sen.j: 政治的才能には長けていたが、それでも応仁の乱を勃発させて国人層の台頭を招くなど、結果として戦国時代の幕を開くことになった張本人の一人であることは間違いない人物である。
sen.e: Although he had high political skills, it is no mistake that he was one of the very people who started the Onin War, triggered the rise of local samurais, and finally started the Sengoku era as a result.
Although he had high political skills, he was undoubtedly one of the people who started the Onin War, triggered the rise of local samurais and ultimately started the Sengoku era as a result.

Although he had high political skills, he was undoubtedly one of the people who started the Onin War, triggered the rise of local samurais and ultimately started the he Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) as a result.
sen.cmt: Sengoku era→the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States)

tit.e: Record of Official Titles and Ranks
Record of Official Titles and Ranks
Record of Official Titles and Ranks

sen.j: 日付は旧暦
sen.e: Dates shown are based on the lunar calendar.
Dates shown are based on the lunar calendar.
Dates shown are based on the lunar calendar.

sen.j: 1442年（嘉吉2年）8月 - 細川氏当主となる。
sen.e: August, 1442: He became the head of the Hosokawa family.
August, 1442: He became the head of the Hosokawa family.
August, 1442: Became head of the Hosokawa clan.
sen.cmt: スタイルの問題。 “He xxx”という形が使われているが、提案としては-> “Became head of the Hosokawa clan”

sen.j: 征夷大将軍足利義勝の名を一字賜り、勝元と名乗る。
sen.e: Borrowing one of the characters of the name of the Seii Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo) Yoshikatsu ASHIKAGA, he named himself Katsumoto.
Borrowing one of the characters of the name of the Seii Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo) Yoshikatsu ASHIKAGA, he named himself Katsumoto.
Borrowing one of the characters of the name of the Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") Yoshikatsu ASHIKAGA, he named himself Katsumoto.
sen.cmt: (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo)→(literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")

sen.j: 併せて従五位京職に叙任。
sen.e: At the same time he was appointed to central administration personnel of the junior fifth court rank.
At the same time he was appointed to serve in the central administration with the rank of junior fifth court.
At the same time he was appointed to serve in the central administration with the rank of Jugoi (junior fifth court).
sen.cmt: Jugoiと括弧を補足しました。

sen.j: 年月日不詳 - 武蔵国を兼任。
sen.e: Unknown date: He took charge of the Province of Musashi.
Unknown date: He took charge of the Province of Musashi.
Unknown date: Took charge of the Musashi Province.
sen.cmt: スタイルの問題。 “He xxx”という形が使われているが、提案としては-> Took...

sen.j: 年月日不詳 - 従四位に昇叙。
sen.e: Unknown date: He was promoted to the junior fourth court rank.
sen.cmt: 従四位に昇叙→promoted to Jnior fourth court rank→promoted to junior fourth court rank
sen.e: Unknown date: He was promoted to the junior fourth court rank.
Unknown date: Promoted to the Jushii (junior fourth rank).
sen.cmt: junior fourth court rank→Jushii (junior fourth rank)スタイルの問題。 “He xxx”という形が使われているが、提案としては-> Promoted …

sen.j: 1445年（文安2年）3月29日 - 室町幕府の管領に就任。
sen.e: March 29, 1445: He became a kanrei, or a shogunal deputy, of the Muromachi shogunate.
March 29, 1445: He became a kanrei (a shogunal deputy) of the Muromachi shogunate.
March 29, 1445: Became a kanrei (a shogunal deputy) of the Muromachi bakufu.
sen.cmt: スタイルの問題。 “He xxx”という形が使われているが、提案としては-> “Became...”

sen.j: 1449年（宝徳元年）10月5日 - 管領を辞任。
sen.e: October 5, 1449: He resigned as a kanrei, or a shogunal deputy.
October 5, 1449: He resigned as a kanrei.
October 5, 1449: He resigned as a kanrei.

sen.j: 1452年（享徳元年）11月26日 - 幕府の管領に再度就任。
sen.e: November 26, 1452: He once again became a kanrei, or a shogunal deputy, of the Muromachi shogunate.
November 26, 1452: He again became a kanrei of the Muromachi shogunate.
November 26, 1452: Again became a kanrei of the Muromachi bakufu.
sen.cmt: スタイルの問題。 “He xxx”という形が使われているが、提案としては-> “Became...”
